What it is (quick overview): A GRACE-era glacier/ice-cap mass-change estimate (reported as a mass-change rate, i.e.,dm/dtdm/dtdm/dt, in the original study).
Source / how to cite: Jacob, T., Wahr, J., Pfeffer, W. T. & Swenson, S. “Recent contributions of glaciers and ice caps to sea level rise.”Nature(2012).

What it is (quick overview): A GRACE-based global glacier mass-loss assessment for the GRACE mission period (2002–2016 in the cited paper).
Source / how to cite: Wouters, B., Gardner, A. S. & Moholdt, G. “Global glacier mass loss during the GRACE satellite mission 2002–2016.”Frontiers in Earth Science(2019).

What it is (quick overview): A WGMS in situ (glaciological) glacier mass-balance series aggregated as a mean balance time series (used by GlaMBIE primarily for interannual variability).
Source / how to cite: WGMS glaciological observations / FoG-based products as used in GlaMBIE (see WGMS references in the paper and the GlaMBIE WGMS data release).

What it is (quick overview): A derived “regional glaciological time series” used for temporal handling in GlaMBIE workflows (the paper describes downscaling glaciological series from seasonal to monthly using an analytical approach for hydrological↔calendar-year handling).
Observation method class in GlaMBIE: Internal/derived glaciological support series used in processing (temporal correction), rather than a primary remote-sensing method.
Source / how to cite: Cite the GlaMBIE dataset/paper, and (for the downscaling method) Zemp, M. & Welty, E. “Temporal downscaling of glaciological mass balance using seasonal observations.”Journal of Glaciology(2023).

What it is (quick overview): A GRACE/GRACE-FO gravimetry solution associated with the AWI (Alfred Wegener Institute) group led by Sasgen, used as one of the gravimetry contributions in GlaMBIE.
Source / how to cite: Sasgen, I. et al. “Arctic glaciers record wavier circumpolar winds.”Nature Climate Change(2022).

What it is (quick overview): A GRACE gravimetry-derived regional ice-mass change product (seasonal cycles + trends) contributed by the Harig/Simons group and used among GlaMBIE’s gravimetry inputs.
Source / how to cite: Harig, C. & Simons, F. J. “Ice mass loss in Greenland, the Gulf of Alaska, and the Canadian Archipelago: seasonal cycles and decadal trends.”Geophysical Research Letters(2016).

What it is (quick overview): An input linked to the widely used reconciled estimate of glacier contribution to sea-level rise for 2003–2009 (the paper cites this as a key earlier synthesis), and in the GlaMBIE context this appears as a contributed time series product (dataset ID includes “icesat” in its name).
Observation method class in GlaMBIE: Hybrid/synthesis-type contribution referenced in GlaMBIE’s background literature (the paper treats such combined-method products as “hybrid estimates” when submitted as inputs).
Source / how to cite: Gardner, A. S. et al. “A reconciled estimate of glacier contributions to sea level rise: 2003 to 2009.”Science(2013).

What it is (quick overview): An ICESat laser-altimetry-based glacier change estimate (dataset name indicates ICESat) associated with Treichler; ICESat-era altimetry is explicitly listed among the altimetry inputs used by GlaMBIE.
Source / how to cite: Treichler, D., Kääb, A., Salzmann, N. & Xu, C.-Y. “Recent glacier and lake changes in High Mountain Asia and their relation to precipitation changes.”The Cryosphere(2019).
